content:
Classifying includes looking at a user input and a given a set of criteria, including a list of possible intents and entities, and determining if any of the intents are sufficient to match the input.  Multiple intents can be returned, if applicable. If an intent is deemed to be a good match, then entities associated with that intent should be reviewed to see if the input contains any entity information as defined in the criteria.  Not all intents have entities associated with them. When looking at entities, you may see some “slot-examples”.  These represent the only values that could be returned for that entity.  You may also see regex patterns as “possible_values”.  If a value meets the regex criteria, it can be returned as a value for that entity.  

Regarding the format for your response, it should be a YAML.  For any intent returned, all corresponding entities should also be returned with values as found in the user input.  If no entity value is found, populate the entity value with “None found”.  When constructing your YAML, return only the identifier for both the intents and entities, along with the entity values.  

Example:

- intent identifier:
  entity identifier: entity value


User input:

release 42% of VM008

chosen:
- c265b26daafa42fdb63fc6e:
  3560c64400ea4a2b914c0a4: VM008
  769d5f404e9a4fc2b537f7c: None found
  31b5b4ff97414fb380edd67: None found
rejected:
- c265b26daafa42fdb63fc6e
  resource_type: None found
  resource_name: VM008
  release_percentage: 42%
